In-class exercise 3

Published

January 22, 2024

Revising Hands-on Exercise 3

In this in-class exercise, we will be using the following packages:

  • maptools
  • sf
  • spatstat
  • tmap
  • tidyverse
Show the code 
pacman::p_load(maptools, sf, raster, spatstat, tmap, tidyverse)

As there may be issues with installing maptools, you may use the following:

Show the code 
install.packages("maptools", repos = "https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/2023-10-13")

After that, you can rerun the first code block.

Data import

Import the data using the following:

Show the code 
mpsz_sf <- st_read(dsn='data/geospatial',
                   layer = 'MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL')
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `D:\KrisLBT\IS415-GAA\In-class_Ex\In-class_Ex03\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
Show the code 
childcare_sf <- st_read("data/geospatial/ChildCareServices.geojson")
Reading layer `ChildCareServices' from data source 
  `D:\KrisLBT\IS415-GAA\In-class_Ex\In-class_Ex03\data\geospatial\ChildCareServices.geojson' 
  using driver `GeoJSON'
Simple feature collection with 1925 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

We notice that childcare_sf is in WGS 84. We can transform it using the following code block.

Show the code 
childcare_sf <- st_transform(childcare_sf, 3414)

Deriving CoastalOutline

First, we can plot the Master Plan Subzone Boundary 2014

Show the code 
plot(mpsz_sf)

Then we can blend away the boundaries.

Show the code 
sg_sf <- mpsz_sf %>%
  st_union()
Show the code 
plot(sg_sf)

We use st_union() over st_combine() as st_union() will treat the output as a singular polygon while st_combine() will treat the individual subzones as their own polygon.

With that, we have made the CoastalOutline

Geospatial Data Wrangling

Creating ppp objects: sf method

We can use the more efficient as.ppp() method to convert to ppp.

Show the code 
childcare_ppp <- as.ppp(childcare_sf)
Show the code 
summary(childcare_ppp)
Marked planar point pattern:  1925 points
Average intensity 2.417323e-06 points per square unit

Coordinates are given to 3 decimal places
i.e. rounded to the nearest multiple of 0.001 units

marks are of type 'character'
Summary:
   Length     Class      Mode 
     1925 character character 

Window: rectangle = [11810.03, 45404.24] x [25596.33, 49300.88] units
                    (33590 x 23700 units)
Window area = 796335000 square units

Creating owin object

Show the code 
sg_owin <- as.owin(sg_sf)
Show the code 
plot(sg_owin)

From here on out, the steps are the same.

Show the code 
pg <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "PUNGGOL")
tm <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "TAMPINES")
ck <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "CHOA CHU KANG")
jw <- mpsz_sf %>%
  filter(PLN_AREA_N == "JURONG WEST")

Plotting

Show the code 
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
plot(pg, main= "Punggol")

Show the code 
plot(tm, main = "Tampines")

Show the code 
plot(ck, main = "Choa Chu Kang")

Show the code 
plot(jw, main= "Jurong West")
